1463.text: Growing apart doesn't change the fact that for a long time we grew side by side; our roots will always be tangled. I'm glad for that.
1463.author: Ally Condie

1464.text: I woke up thinking a very pleasant thought. There is lots left in the world to read.
1464.author: Nicholson Baker

1465.text: We are just an advanced breed of monkeys on a minor planet of a very average star. But we can understand the Universe. That makes us something very special.
1465.author: Stephen Hawking

1466.text: I crave your mouth, your voice, your hair.
1466.author: Pablo Neruda

1467.text: What and how much had I lost by trying to do only what was expected of me instead of what I myself had wished to do?
1467.author: Ralph Ellison

1468.text: I love you like a fat kid loves cake!
1468.author: Scott Adams

1469.text: The past has no power over the present moment.
1469.author: Eckhart Tolle

1470.text: To say goodbye is to die a little.
1470.author: Raymond Chandler

1471.text: When I discover who I am, I’ll be free.
1471.author: Ralph Ellison

1472.text: Time is an illusion. Lunchtime doubly so.
1472.author: Douglas Adams

1473.text: Success is getting what you want, happiness is wanting what you get
1473.author: W.P. Kinsella

1474.text: Words are pale shadows of forgotten names. As names have power, words have power. Words can light fires in the minds of men. Words can wring tears from the hardest hearts.
1474.author: Patrick Rothfuss

1475.text: Everyone you will ever meet knows something you don't.
1475.author: Bill Nye

1476.text: If you want to be a writer, you must do two things above all others: read a lot and write a lot.
1476.author: Stephen King

1477.text: Live in the present, remember the past, and fear not the future, for it doesn't exist and never shall. There is only now.
1477.author: Christopher Paolini

1478.text: We all bear scars,... Mine just happen to be more visible than most.
1478.author: Sarah J. Maas

1479.text: It was not the feeling of completeness I so needed, but the feeling of not being empty.
1479.author: Jonathan Safran Foer

1480.text: And when her lips met mine, I knew that I could live to be a hundred and visit every country in the world, but nothing would ever compare to that single moment when I first kissed the girl of my dreams and knew that my love would last forever.
1480.author: Nicholas Sparks

1481.text: Travel is fatal to prejudice, bigotry, and narrow-mindedness, and many of our people need it sorely on these accounts. Broad, wholesome, charitable views of men and things cannot be acquired by vegetating in one little corner of the earth all one's lifetime.
1481.author: Mark Twain

1482.text: You will lose someone you can’t live without,and your heart will be badly broken, and the bad news is that you never completely get over the loss of your beloved. But this is also the good news. They live forever in your broken heart that doesn’t seal back up. And you come through. It’s like having a broken leg that never heals perfectly—that still hurts when the weather gets cold, but you learn to dance with the limp.
1482.author: Anne Lamott

1483.text: Jesper knocked his head against the hull and cast his eyes heavenward. Fine. But if Pekka Rollins kills us all, I’m going to get Wylan’s ghost to teach my ghost how to play the flute just so that I can annoy the hell out of your ghost.
1483.author: Leigh Bardugo

1484.text: Welcome to the wonderful world of jealousy, he thought. For the price of admission, you get a splitting headache, a nearly irresistable urge to commit murder, and an inferiority complex. Yippee.
1484.author: J.R. Ward

1485.text: I can shake off everything as I write; my sorrows disappear, my courage is reborn.
1485.author: Anne Frank

1486.text: People think that intimacy is about sex. But intimacy is about truth. When you realize you can tell someone your truth, when you can show yourself to them, when you stand in front of them bare and their response is 'you're safe with me'- that's intimacy.
1486.author: Taylor Jenkins Reid

1487.text: Do not fear failure but rather fear not trying.
1487.author: Roy T. Bennett

1488.text: Hello babies. Welcome to Earth. It's hot in the summer and cold in the winter. It's round and wet and crowded. On the outside, babies, you've got a hundred years here. There's only one rule that I know of, babies-"God damn it, you've got to be kind.
1488.author: Kurt Vonnegut

1489.text: What you do speaks so loudly that I cannot hear what you say.
1489.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

1490.text: If you want to tell people the truth, make them laugh, otherwise they'll kill you.
1490.author: George Bernard Shaw

1491.text: The best moments in reading are when you come across something – a thought, a feeling, a way of looking at things – which you had thought special and particular to you. Now here it is, set down by someone else, a person you have never met, someone even who is long dead. And it is as if a hand has come out and taken yours.
1491.author: Alan Bennett

1492.text: Knock, And He'll open the door
1492.author: Jalal Ad-Din Rumi

1493.text: You never know what worse luck your bad luck has saved you from.
1493.author: Cormac McCarthy

1494.text: Maybe...you'll fall in love with me all over again."
1494.author: Ernest Hemingway

1495.text: That it will never come again is what makes life so sweet.
1495.author: Emily Dickinson

1496.text: Yeah, Quirrell was a great teacher. There was just that minor drawback of him having Lord Voldemort sticking out of the back of his head!
1496.author: J.K. Rowling

1497.text: He stepped down, trying not to look long at her, as if she were the sun, yet he saw her, like the sun, even without looking.
1497.author: Leo Tolstoy

1498.text: Have you ever noticed that anybody driving slower than you is an idiot, and anyone going faster than you is a maniac?
1498.author: George Carlin

1499.text: Take pride in your pain; you are stronger than those who have none
1499.author: Lois Lowry

1500.text: You must make a decision that you are going to move on. It wont happen automatically. You will have to rise up and say, ‘I don’t care how hard this is, I don’t care how disappointed I am, I’m not going to let this get the best of me. I’m moving on with my life.
1500.author: Joel Osteen

1501.text: Education is the ability to listen to almost anything without losing your temper or your self-confidence.
1501.author: Robert Frost

1502.text: If we wait for the moment when everything, absolutely everything is ready, we shall never begin.
1502.author: Ivan Turgenev

1503.text: Never say 'no' to adventures. Always say 'yes,' otherwise you'll lead a very dull life.
1503.author: Ian Fleming

1504.text: Love is an untamed force. When we try to control it, it destroys us. When we try to imprison it, it enslaves us. When we try to understand it, it leaves us feeling lost and confused.
1504.author: Paulo Coelho

1505.text: Money can't buy happiness, but it can make you awfully comfortable while you're being miserable.
1505.author: Clare Boothe Luce

1507.text: You can't measure the mutual affection of two human beings by the number of words they exchange.
1507.author: Milan Kundera

1510.text: Though she be but little, she is fierce!
1510.author: William Shakespeare

1511.text: I nodded, looking at Rachel with respect. "You hit the Lord of the Titans in the eye with a blue plastic hairbrush.
1511.author: Rick Riordan

1512.text: So you're always honest," I said.
1512.author: Sarah Dessen

1513.text: So it's you and a syringe against the Capitol? See, this is why no one lets you make the plans.
1513.author: Suzanne Collins

1514.text: ‎Life is a shipwreck, but we must not forget to sing in the lifeboats.
1514.author: Voltaire

1515.text: The reasonable man adapts himself to the world: the unreasonable one persists in trying to adapt the world to himself. Therefore all progress depends on the unreasonable man.
1515.author: George Bernard Shaw

1517.text: If you treat an individual as he is, he will remain how he is. But if you treat him as if he were what he ought to be and could be, he will become what he ought to be and could be.
1517.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

1518.text: you can, you should, and if you’re brave enough to start, you will.
1518.author: Stephen King

1519.text: When it is dark enough, you can see the stars.
1519.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

1520.text: The meek may inherit the earth, but at the moment it belongs to the conceited. Like me.
1520.author: Cassandra Clare

1521.text: Reading furnishes the mind only with materials of knowledge; it is thinking that makes what we read ours.
1521.author: John Locke

1522.text: We must be willing to let go of the life we planned so as to have the life that is waiting for us.
1522.author: Joseph Campbell

1523.text: You think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read.
1523.author: James Baldwin

1524.text: If I cannot be better than them, I will become so much worse.
1524.author: Holly Black

1525.text: Every great love starts with a great story...
1525.author: Nicholas Sparks

1526.text: Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead.
1526.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

1527.text: There are three rules for writing a novel. Unfortunately, no one knows what they are.
1527.author: W. Somerset Maugham

1528.text: The only way to get through life is to laugh your way through it. You either have to laugh or cry. I prefer to laugh. Crying gives me a headache.
1528.author: Marjorie Pay Hinckley

1529.text: So many things are possible just as long as you don't know they're impossible.
1529.author: Norton Juster

1530.text: And I thought about how many people have loved those songs. And how many people got through a lot of bad times because of those songs. And how many people enjoyed good times with those songs. And how much those songs really mean. I think it would be great to have written one of those songs. I bet if I wrote one of them, I would be very proud. I hope the people who wrote those songs are happy. I hope they feel it's enough. I really do because they've made me happy. And I'm only one person.
1530.author: Stephen Chbosky

1531.text: Every man I meet wants to protect me. I can't figure out what from.
1531.author: Mae West

1532.text: Books should go where they will be most appreciated, and not sit unread, gathering dust on a forgotten shelf, don't you agree?
1532.author: Christopher Paolini

1533.text: Life, he realize, was much like a song. In the beginning there is mystery, in the end there is confirmation, but it's in the middle where all the emotion resides to make the whole thing worthwhile.
1533.author: Nicholas Sparks

1534.text: I could not tell you if I loved you the first moment I saw you, or if it was the second or third or fourth. But I remember the first moment I looked at you walking toward me and realized that somehow the rest of the world seemed to vanish when I was with you.
1534.author: Cassandra Clare

1535.text: What is that you express in your eyes? It seems to me more than all the print I have read in my life.
1535.author: Walt Whitman

1536.text: Love is a temporary madness, it erupts like volcanoes and then subsides. And when it subsides, you have to make a decision. You have to work out whether your roots have so entwined together that it is inconceivable that you should ever part. Because this is what love is. Love is not breathlessness, it is not excitement, it is not the promulgation of promises of eternal passion, it is not the desire to mate every second minute of the day, it is not lying awake at night imagining that he is kissing every cranny of your body. No, don't blush, I am telling you some truths. That is just being "in love", which any fool can do. Love itself is what is left over when being in love has burned away, and this is both an art and a fortunate accident.
1536.author: Shawn Slovo

1537.text: If I got rid of my demons, I’d lose my angels.
1537.author: Tennessee Williams

1538.text: A ship is safe in harbor, but that's not what ships are for.
1538.author: John A. Shedd

1539.text: No woman really wants a man to carry her off; she only wants him to want to do it.
1539.author: Elizabeth Peters

1540.text: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
1540.author: Marcus Aurelius

1541.text: You couldn't relive your life, skipping the awful parts, without losing what made it worthwhile. You had to accept it as a whole--like the world, or the person you loved.
1541.author: Stewart O'Nan

1542.text: I realize now that dying is easy. Living is hard.
1542.author: Gayle Forman

1543.text: What if it lines up like it did in the Trojan War ... Athena versus Poseidon?"
1543.author: Rick Riordan

1544.text: Everybody talks about wanting to change things and help and fix, but ultimately all you can do is fix yourself. And that's a lot. Because if you can fix yourself, it has a ripple effect.
1544.author: Rob Reiner

1545.text: Life is a series of natural and spontaneous changes. Don't resist them; that only creates sorrow. Let reality be reality. Let things flow naturally forward in whatever way they like.
1545.author: Lao Tzu

1546.text: Cowards die many times before their deaths;
1546.author: William Shakespeare

1547.text: Crying is all right in its way while it lasts. But you have to stop sooner or later, and then you still have to decide what to do.
1547.author: C.S. Lewis

1548.text: All your life, you will be faced with a choice. You can choose love or hate…I choose love.
1548.author: Johnny Cash

1549.text: In politics, If you want anything said, ask a man. If you want anything done, ask a woman.
1549.author: Margaret Thatcher

1550.text: It's just that most really good-looking people are stupid, so I exceed expectations.'
1550.author: John Green

1551.text: To be, or not to be: that is the question:
1551.author: William Shakespeare

1552.text: And when at last you find someone to whom you feel you can pour out your soul, you stop in shock at the words you utter— they are so rusty, so ugly, so meaningless and feeble from being kept in the small cramped dark inside you so long.
1552.author: Sylvia Plath

1553.text: I'm not young enough to know everything.
1553.author: J.M. Barrie

1554.text: I cannot teach anybody anything. I can only make them think
1554.author: Socrates

1555.text: Always find opportunities to make someone smile, and to offer random acts of kindness in everyday life.
1555.author: Roy T. Bennett

1556.text: She read books as one would breathe air, to fill up and live.
1556.author: Annie Dillard

1557.text: If you are a dreamer come in
1557.author: Shel Silverstein

1558.text: If you ask me what I came to do in this world, I, an artist, will answer you: I am here to live out loud.
1558.author: Émile Zola

1559.text: I knew when I met you an adventure was going to happen.
1559.author: A.A. Milne

1560.text: Be clearly aware of the stars and infinity on high. Then life seems almost enchanted after all.
1560.author: Vincent Van Gogh

1561.text: There is no exquisite beauty… without some strangeness in the proportion.
1561.author: Edgar Allan Poe

1562.text: If you don't like someone's story, write your own.
1562.author: Chinua Achebe

1563.text: The real story of the Fleece: there were these two children of Zeus, Cadmus and Europa, okay? They were about to get offered up as human sacrifices, when they prayed to Zeus to save them. So Zeus sent this magical flying ram with golden wool, which picked them up in Greece and carried them all the way to Colchis in Asia Minor. Well, actually it carried Cadmus. Europa fell off and died along the way, but that's not important."
1563.author: Rick Riordan

1564.text: Failure is the condiment that gives success its flavor.
1564.author: Truman Capote

1565.text: Youth is happy because it has the capacity to see beauty. Anyone who keeps the ability to see beauty never grows old.
1565.author: Franz Kafka

1567.text: All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man does, and that is his.
1567.author: Oscar Wilde

1568.text: Biology gives you a brain. Life turns it into a mind.
1568.author: Jeffrey Eugenides

1569.text: I came from a real tough neighborhood. Once a guy pulled a knife on me. I knew he wasn't a professional, the knife had butter on it.
1569.author: Rodney Dangerfield

1570.text: And then he gives me a smile that just seems so genuinely sweet with just the right touch of shyness that unexpected warmth rushes through me.
1570.author: Suzanne Collins

1571.text: It's a lot easier to be lost than found. It's the reason we're always searching and rarely discovered--so many locks not enough keys.
1571.author: Sarah Dessen

1572.text: Anyone whose goal is 'something higher' must expect someday to suffer vertigo. What is vertigo? Fear of falling? No, Vertigo is something other than fear of falling. It is the voice of the emptiness below us which tempts and lures us, it is the desire to fall, against which, terrified, we defend ourselves.
1572.author: Milan Kundera

1573.text: Why were you lurking under our window?"
1573.author: J.K. Rowling

1574.text: I regret that it takes a life to learn how to live.
1574.author: Jonathan Safran Foer

1575.text: Everyone is a moon, and has a dark side which he never shows to anybody.
1575.author: Mark Twain

1576.text: Rivers know this: there is no hurry. We shall get there some day.
1576.author: A.A. Milne

1577.text: There is no mistaking a real book when one meets it. It is like falling in love.
1577.author: Christopher Morley

1578.text: The only way to get rid of temptation is to yield to it.
1578.author: Oscar Wilde

1579.text: Sometimes,' said Pooh, 'the smallest things take up the most room in your heart.
1579.author: A.A. Milne

1580.text: Any fool knows men and women think differently at times, but the biggest difference is this. Men forget, but never forgive; women forgive, but never forget.
1580.author: Robert Jordan

1581.text: Appear weak when you are strong, and strong when you are weak.
1581.author: Sun Tzu

1582.text: Before you, Bella, my life was like a moonless night. Very dark, but there were stars, points of light and reason. ...And then you shot across my sky like a meteor. Suddenly everything was on fire; there was brilliancy, there was beauty. When you were gone, when the meteor had fallen over the horizon, everything went black. Nothing had changed, but my eyes were blinded by the light. I couldn’t see the stars anymore. And there was no more reason, for anything.
1582.author: Stephenie Meyer

1583.text: A single dream is more powerful than a thousand realities.
1583.author: Nathaniel Hawthorne

1584.text: One can never have enough socks," said Dumbledore. "Another Christmas has come and gone and I didn't get a single pair. People will insist on giving me books.
1584.author: J.K. Rowling

1585.text: If you don't know, the thing to do is not to get scared, but to learn.
1585.author: Ayn Rand

1586.text: She says nothing at all, but simply stares upward into the dark sky and watches, with sad eyes, the slow dance of the infinite stars.
1586.author: Neil Gaiman

1587.text: When I am with you, we stay up all night.
1587.author: Rumi

1588.text: A book is really like a lover. It arranges itself in your life in a way that is beautiful.
1588.author: Maurice Sendak

1589.text: Some people say, Never let them see you cry. I say, if you’re so mad you could just cry, then cry. It terrifies everyone.
1589.author: Tina Fey

1590.text: Have no fear of perfection - you'll never reach it.
1590.author: Salvador Dali

1591.text: I've got nothing to do today but smile.
1591.author: Simon and Garfunkel

1592.text: That's why they call it the American Dream, because you have to be asleep to believe it.
1592.author: George Carlin

1593.text: America will never be destroyed from the outside. If we falter and lose our freedoms, it will be because we destroyed ourselves.
1593.author: Abraham Lincoln

1594.text: Some lose all mind and become soul,insane.
1594.author: Charles Bukowski

1595.text: Letting go doesn't mean that you don't care about someone anymore. It's just realizing that the only person you really have control over is yourself.
1595.author: Deborah Reber

1596.text: Books say: She did this because. Life says: She did this. Books are where things are explained to you; life is where things aren't. I'm not surprised some people prefer books.
1596.author: Julian Barnes

1597.text: You wanna fly, you got to give up the shit that weighs you down.
1597.author: Toni Morrison

1598.text: All the secrets of the world are contained in books. Read at your own risk.
1598.author: Lemony Snicket

1599.text: I stood still, vision blurring, and in that moment, I heard my heart break. It was a small, clean sound, like the snapping of a flower's stem.
1599.author: Diana Gabaldon

1600.text: The best thing for being sad," replied Merlin, beginning to puff and blow, "is to learn something. That's the only thing that never fails. You may grow old and trembling in your anatomies, you may lie awake at night listening to the disorder of your veins, you may miss your only love, you may see the world about you devastated by evil lunatics, or know your honour trampled in the sewers of baser minds. There is only one thing for it then — to learn. Learn why the world wags and what wags it. That is the only thing which the mind can never exhaust, never alienate, never be tortured by, never fear or distrust, and never dream of regretting. Learning is the only thing for you. Look what a lot of things there are to learn.
1600.author: T.H. White

1601.text: Perhaps the greatest faculty our minds possess is the ability to cope with pain. Classic thinking teaches us of the four doors of the mind, which everyone moves through according to their need.
1601.author: Patrick Rothfuss

1602.text: When people don't express themselves, they die one piece at a time.
1602.author: Laurie Halse Anderson

1603.text: You can cut all the flowers but you cannot keep Spring from coming.
1603.author: Pablo Neruda

1604.text: Behind every exquisite thing that existed, there was something tragic.
1604.author: Oscar Wilde

1605.text: It's funny how humans can wrap their mind around things and fit them into their version of reality.
1605.author: Rick Riordan

1606.text: Tears shed for another person are not a sign of weakness. They are a sign of a pure heart.
1606.author: José N. Harris

1607.text: It's often just enough to be with someone. I don't need to touch them. Not even talk. A feeling passes between you both. You're not alone.
1607.author: Marilyn Monroe

1608.text: I realize only one person will be damaged beyond repair if Peeta dies. Me.
1608.author: Suzanne Collins

1609.text: The pessimist complains about the wind; the optimist expects it to change; the realist adjusts the sails.
1609.author: William Arthur Ward

1610.text: A good traveler has no fixed plans and is not intent on arriving.
1610.author: Lao Tzu

1611.text: We are cups, constantly and quietly being filled. The trick is, knowing how to tip ourselves over and let the beautiful stuff out.
1611.author: Ray Bradbury

1612.text: In life, unlike chess, the game continues after checkmate.
1612.author: Isaac Asimov

1613.text: Children must be taught how to think, not what to think.
1613.author: Margaret Mead

1614.text: A common mistake that people make when trying to design something completely foolproof is to underestimate the ingenuity of complete fools.
1614.author: Douglas Adams

1615.text: Clothes make the man. Naked people have little or no influence on society.
1615.author: Mark Twain

1617.text: I have absolutely no pleasure in the stimulants in which I sometimes so madly indulge. It has not been in the pursuit of pleasure that I have periled life and reputation and reason. It has been the desperate attempt to escape from torturing memories, from a sense of insupportable loneliness and a dread of some strange impending doom.
1617.author: Edgar Allan Poe

1618.text: There are so many fragile things, after all. People break so easily, and so do dreams and hearts.
1618.author: Neil Gaiman

1619.text: The unreal is more powerful than the real. Because nothing is as perfect as you can imagine it. Because its only intangible ideas, concepts, beliefs, fantasies that last. Stone crumbles. Wood rots. People, well, they die. But things as fragile as a thought, a dream, a legend, they can go on and on. If you can change the way people think. The way they see themselves. The way they see the world. You can change the way people live their lives. That's the only lasting thing you can create.
1619.author: Chuck Palahniuk

1620.text: I've found that there is always some beauty left -- in nature, sunshine, freedom, in yourself; these can all help you.
1620.author: Anne Frank

1621.text: Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another.
1621.author: Carl Sagan

1622.text: Remember to always be yourself. Unless you suck.
1622.author: Joss Whedon

1624.text: The most common way people give up their power is by thinking they don't have any.
1624.author: Alice Walker

1626.text: A writer is someone for whom writing is more difficult than it is for other people.
1626.author: Thomas Mann

1627.text: I am selfish. I am brave.
1627.author: Veronica Roth

1628.text: I am trying here to prevent anyone saying the really foolish thing that people often say about Him: I’m ready to accept Jesus as a great moral teacher, but I don’t accept his claim to be God. That is the one thing we must not say. A man who was merely a man and said the sort of things Jesus said would not be a great moral teacher. He would either be a lunatic — on the level with the man who says he is a poached egg — or else he would be the Devil of Hell. You must make your choice. Either this man was, and is, the Son of God, or else a madman or something worse. You can shut him up for a fool, you can spit at him and kill him as a demon or you can fall at his feet and call him Lord and God, but let us not come with any patronizing nonsense about his being a great human teacher. He has not left that open to us. He did not intend to.
1628.author: C.S. Lewis

1629.text: Dogs never bite me. Just humans.
1629.author: Marilyn Monroe

1630.text: I cannot sleep unless I am surrounded by books.
1630.author: Jorge Luis Borges

1631.text: Success is stumbling from failure to failure with no loss of enthusiasm.
1631.author: Winston S. Churchill

1632.text: Sometimes when I look at you, I feel I'm gazing at a distant star.
1632.author: Haruki Murakami

1633.text: It was, he thought, the difference between being dragged into the arena to face a battle to the death and walking into the arena with your head held high. Some people, perhaps, would say that there was little to choose between the two ways, but Dumbledore knew - and so do I, thought Harry, with a rush of fierce pride, and so did my parents - that there was all the difference in the world.
1633.author: J.K. Rowling

1634.text: You cannot pick and choose what parts of her to love.
1634.author: Sarah J. Maas

1635.text: I loved you like a man loves a woman he never touches, only writes to, keeps little photographs of.
1635.author: Charles Bukowski

1636.text: I'm not going to wear a red dress," she said.
1636.author: Kristin Cashore

1637.text: I think there's just one kind of folks. Folks.
1637.author: Harper Lee

1638.text: It is my belief... that the truth is generally preferable to lies.
1638.author: J.K. Rowling

1639.text: Sometimes when I'm talking, my words can't keep up with my thoughts. I wonder why we think faster than we speak. Probably so we can think twice.
1639.author: Bill Watterson

1640.text: There is a sacredness in tears....They are the messengers of overwhelming grief, of deep contrition and of unspeakable love.
1640.author: Washington Irving

1641.text: أتمنى أن أبكي و أرتجف , التصق بواحد من الكبار , لكن الحقيقة القاسية هي أنك الكبار! .. أنت من يجب أن يمنح القوة و الأمن للآخرين!
1641.author: أحمد خالد توفيق

1642.text: Stay gold, Ponyboy. Stay gold . . . The pillow seemed to sink a little, and Johnny died.
1642.author: S.E. Hinton

1643.text: You will find that it is necessary to let things go; simply for the reason that they are heavy. So let them go, let go of them. I tie no weights to my ankles.
1643.author: C. JoyBell C.

1644.text: I think we ought to read only the kind of books that wound or stab us. If the book we're reading doesn't wake us up with a blow to the head, what are we reading for? So that it will make us happy, as you write? Good Lord, we would be happy precisely if we had no books, and the kind of books that make us happy are the kind we could write ourselves if we had to. But we need books that affect us like a disaster, that grieve us deeply, like the death of someone we loved more than ourselves, like being banished into forests far from everyone, like a suicide. A book must be the axe for the frozen sea within us. That is my belief.
1644.author: Franz Kafka

1645.text: I'm tough, I'm ambitious, and I know exactly what I want. If that makes me a bitch, okay.
1645.author: Madonna

1646.text: I am too fond of reading books to care to write them.
1646.author: Oscar Wilde

1647.text: It's like Tolstoy said. Happiness is an allegory, unhappiness a
1647.author: Haruki Murakami

1648.text: Out of suffering have emerged the strongest souls; the most massive characters are seared with scars.
1648.author: Kahlil Gibran

1649.text: You endure what is unbearable, and you bear it. That is all.
1649.author: Cassandra Clare

1650.text: Much of my life had been devoted to trying not to cry in front of people who loved me, so I knew what Augustus was doing. You clench your teeth. You look up. You tell yourself that if they see you cry, it will hurt them, and you will be nothing but a Sadness in their lives, and you must not become a mere sadness, so you will not cry, and you say all of this to yourself while looking up at the ceiling, and then you swallow even though your throat does not want to close and you look at the person who loves you and smile.
1650.author: John Green

1651.text: Real loneliness is not necessarily limited to when you are alone.
1651.author: Charles Bukowski

1652.text: The clearest way into the Universe is through a forest wilderness.
1652.author: John Muir

1653.text: The capacity for friendship is God's way of apologizing for our families.
1653.author: Jay McInerney

1654.text: You can't depend on your eyes when your imagination is out of focus.
1654.author: Mark Twain

1655.text: If you pick up a starving dog and make him prosperous he will not bite you. This is the principal difference between a dog and man.
1655.author: Mark Twain

1656.text: Better to be strong than pretty and useless.
1656.author: Lilith Saintcrow

1657.text: A truth that's told with bad intent
1657.author: William Blake

1658.text: Raise your words, not voice. It is rain that grows flowers, not thunder.
1658.author: Rumi

1659.text: Anyway, I keep picturing all these little kids playing some game in this big field of rye and all. Thousands of little kids, and nobody's around - nobody big, I mean - except me. And I'm standing on the edge of some crazy cliff. What I have to do, I have to catch everybody if they start to go over the cliff - I mean if they're running and they don't look where they're going I have to come out from somewhere and catch them. That's all I do all day. I'd just be the catcher in the rye and all. I know it's crazy, but that's the only thing I'd really like to be.
1659.author: J. D. Salinger

1660.text: Stuff your eyes with wonder, he said, live as if you'd drop dead in ten seconds. See the world. It's more fantastic than any dream made or paid for in factories.
1660.author: Ray Bradbury

1661.text: Men are afraid that women will laugh at them. Women are afraid that men will kill them.
1661.author: Margaret Atwood

1662.text: We both have war inside us. Sometimes it keeps us alive. Sometimes it threatens to destroy us.
1662.author: Veronica Roth

1663.text: Is it so bad, then, to be misunderstood? Pythagoras was misunderstood, and Socrates, and Jesus, and Luther, and Copernicus, and Galileo, and Newton, and every pure and wise spirit that ever took flesh. To be great is to be misunderstood.
1663.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

1664.text: Ah! There is nothing like staying at home, for real comfort.
1664.author: Jane Austen

1665.text: Maybe everyone can live beyond what they're capable of.
1665.author: Markus Zusak

1666.text: From the moment I picked up your book until I put it down, I was convulsed with laughter. Some day I intend reading it.
1666.author: Groucho Marx

1667.text: But who can say what's best? That's why you need to grab whatever chance you have of happiness where you find it, and not worry about other people too much. My experience tells me that we get no more than two or three such chances in a life time, and if we let them go, we regret it for the rest of our lives.
1667.author: Haruki Murakami

1668.text: People can lose their lives in libraries. They ought to be warned.
1668.author: Saul Bellow

1669.text: I've been homesick for countries I've never been, and longed to be where I couldn't be.
1669.author: John Cheever

1670.text: Don't Gain The World & Lose Your Soul, Wisdom Is Better Than Silver Or Gold.
1670.author: Bob Marley

1671.text: The one thing we can never get enough of is love. And the one thing we never give enough of is love.
1671.author: Henry Miller

1672.text: A learning experience is one of those things that says, 'You know that thing you just did? Don't do that.
1672.author: Douglas Adams

1674.text: You only get one life. It's actually your duty to live it as fully as possible.
1674.author: Jojo Moyes

1675.text: Yesterday is gone. Tomorrow has not yet come. We have only today. Let us begin.
1675.author: Mother Theresa

1676.text: Would it save you a lot of time if I just gave up and went mad now?
1676.author: Douglas Adams

1677.text: We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another; unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made up of layers, cells, constellations.
1677.author: Anais Nin

1678.text: There is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.
1678.author: Oscar Wilde

1679.text: The snake which cannot cast its skin has to die. As well the minds which are prevented from changing their opinions; they cease to be mind.
1679.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

1680.text: You realize that our mistrust of the future makes it hard to give up the past.
1680.author: Chuck Palahniuk

1681.text: Do you want to know who you are? Don't ask. Act! Action will delineate and define you.
1681.author: Thomas Jefferson

1683.text: Science and religion are not at odds. Science is simply too young to understand.
1683.author: Dan Brown

1684.text: Our story has three parts: a beginning, a middle, and an end. And although this is the way all stories unfold, I still can't believe that ours didn't go on forever.
1684.author: Nicholas Sparks

1685.text: Everything that irritates us about others can lead us to an understanding of ourselves.
1685.author: Carl Gustav Jung

1686.text: Of all the trees we could've hit, we had to get one that hits back.
1686.author: J.K. Rowling

1687.text: It's amazing how a little tomorrow can make up for a whole lot of yesterday.
1687.author: John Guare

1688.text: Cruelty does not make a person dishonest, the same way bravery does not make a person kind.
1688.author: Veronica Roth

1689.text: Even if you are on the right track, you’ll get run over if you just sit there.
1689.author: Will Rogers

1690.text: A purpose of human life, no matter who is controlling it, is to love whoever is around to be loved.
1690.author: Kurt Vonnegut

1691.text: Let's think the unthinkable, let's do the undoable. Let us prepare to grapple with the ineffable itself, and see if we may not eff it after all.
1691.author: Douglas Adams

1692.text: And he took her in his arms and kissed her under the sunlit sky, and he cared not that they stood high upon the walls in the sight of many.
1692.author: J.R.R. Tolkien

1693.text: The only way that we can live, is if we grow. The only way that we can grow is if we change. The only way that we can change is if we learn. The only way we can learn is if we are exposed. And the only way that we can become exposed is if we throw ourselves out into the open. Do it. Throw yourself.
1693.author: C. JoyBell C.

1694.text: It's discouraging to think how many people are shocked by honesty and how few by deceit.
1694.author: Noël Coward

1695.text: Great minds are always feared by lesser minds.
1695.author: Dan Brown

1696.text: Three may keep a secret, if two of them are dead.
1696.author: Benjamin Franklin

1697.text: Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact. Everything we see is a perspective, not the truth.
1697.author: Marcus Aurelius

1698.text: Still round the corner there may wait
1698.author: J.R.R. Tolkien

1699.text: She seems so cool, so focused, so quiet, yet her eyes remain fixed upon the horizon. You think you know all there is to know about her immediately upon meeting her, but everything you think you know is wrong. Passion flows through her like a river of blood.
1699.author: Neil Gaiman

1700.text: Don't tell me," Jace said, "Simon's turned himself into an ocelot and you want me to do something about it before Isabelle makes him into a stole. Well, you'll have have to wait till tomorrow. I'm out of commission." He pointed at himself - he was wearing blue pajamas with a hole in the sleeve. "Look. Jammies."
1700.author: Cassandra Clare

1701.text: My Best Friend is a person who will give me a book I have not read.
1701.author: Abraham Lincoln

1702.text: I have come to accept the feeling of not knowing where I am going. And I have trained myself to love it. Because it is only when we are suspended in mid-air with no landing in sight, that we force our wings to unravel and alas begin our flight. And as we fly, we still may not know where we are going to. But the miracle is in the unfolding of the wings. You may not know where you're going, but you know that so long as you spread your wings, the winds will carry you.
1702.author: C. JoyBell C.

1703.text: The best portion of a good man's life: his little, nameless unremembered acts of kindness and love.
1703.author: William Wordsworth

1704.text: being alone never felt right. sometimes it felt good, but it never felt right.
1704.author: Charles Bukowski

1705.text: Art and love are the same thing: It’s the process of seeing yourself in things that are not you.
1705.author: Chuck Klosterman

1706.text: Anyone who falls in love is searching for the missing pieces of themselves. So anyone who's in love gets sad when they think of their lover. It's like stepping back inside a room you have fond memories of, one you haven't seen in a long time.
1706.author: Murakami Haruki

1707.text: Beauty is only skin deep, but ugly goes clean to the bone.
1707.author: Dorothy Parker

1708.text: Music expresses that which cannot be said and on which it is impossible to be silent.
1708.author: Victor Hugo

1709.text: I believe a strong woman may be stronger than a man, particularly if she happens to have love in her heart. I guess a loving woman is indestructible.
1709.author: John Steinbeck

1710.text: If you hate a person, you hate something in him that is part of yourself. What isn't part of ourselves doesn't disturb us.
1710.author: Hermann Hesse

1711.text: You gave me a forever within the numbered days, and I'm grateful.
1711.author: John Green

1712.text: Sometimes it's a form of love just to talk to somebody that you have nothing in common with and still be fascinated by their presence.
1712.author: David Byrne

1714.text: There is no such thing as bad people. We’re all just people who sometimes do bad things.
1714.author: Colleen Hoover

1715.text: When everyone knows you’re a monster, you needn’t waste time doing every monstrous thing.
1715.author: Leigh Bardugo

1716.text: A woman without a man is like a fish without a bicycle.
1716.author: Irina Dunn

1717.text: Respect was invented to cover the empty place where love should be.
1717.author: Leo Tolstoy

1718.text: This is what you shall do; Love the earth and sun and the animals, despise riches, give alms to every one that asks, stand up for the stupid and crazy, devote your income and labor to others, hate tyrants, argue not concerning God, have patience and indulgence toward the people, take off your hat to nothing known or unknown or to any man or number of men, go freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young and with the mothers of families, read these leaves in the open air every season of every year of your life, re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul, and your very flesh shall be a great poem and have the richest fluency not only in its words but in the silent lines of its lips and face and between the lashes of your eyes and in every motion and joint of your body.
1718.author: Walt Whitman

1719.text: Every now and then I like to do as I'm told, just to confuse people.
1719.author: Tamora Pierce

1720.text: Lighthouses don’t go running all over an island looking for boats to save; they just stand there shining.
1720.author: Anne Lamott

1721.text: It's possible to go on, no matter how impossible it seems, and that in time, the grief . . . lessens. It may not go away completely, but after a while it's not so overwhelming.
1721.author: Nicholas Sparks

1722.text: Fools talk, cowards are silent, wise men listen.
1722.author: Carlos Ruiz Zafon

1723.text: I am looking for friends. What does that mean -- tame?"
1723.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

1724.text: I fell in love with you, smartass, because you were one of us—because you weren’t afraid of me, and you decided to end your spectacular victory by throwing that piece of bone at Amarantha like a javelin. I felt Cassian’s spirit beside me in that moment, and could have sworn I heard him say, ‘If you don’t marry her, you stupid prick, I will.
1724.author: Sarah J. Maas

1725.text: Don't be so humble - you are not that great.
1725.author: Golda Meir

1726.text: I knew the second I met you
1726.author: Jamie McGuire

1727.text: If I had a world of my own, everything would be nonsense. Nothing would be what it is, because everything would be what it isn't. And contrary wise, what is, it wouldn't be. And what it wouldn't be, it would. You see?
1727.author: Lewis Carroll

1728.text: It is thanks to my evening reading alone that I am still more or less sane.
1728.author: W.G. Sebald

1729.text: There are books of which the backs and covers are by far the best parts.
1729.author: Charles Dickens

1730.text: When he died, all things soft and beautiful and bright would be buried with him.
1730.author: Madeline Miller

1731.text: I had already found that it was not good to be alone, and so made companionship with what there was around me, sometimes with the universe and sometimes with my own insignificant self; but my books were always my friends, let fail all else.
1731.author: Joshua Slocum

1732.text: My imagination functions much better when I don't have to speak to people.
1732.author: Patricia Highsmith

1733.text: I was wise enough never to grow up, while fooling people into believing I had.
1733.author: Margaret Mead

1734.text: If you don't read the newspaper, you're uninformed. If you read the newspaper, you're mis-informed.
1734.author: Mark Twain

1735.text: Maybe there is a beast… maybe it's only us.
1735.author: William Golding

1736.text: I am constantly torn between killing myself and killing everyone around me.
1736.author: David Levithan

1737.text: It is easier to forgive an enemy than to forgive a friend.
1737.author: William Blake

1738.text: Kindred spirits are not so scarce as I used to think. It's splendid to find out there are so many of them in the world.
1738.author: L.M. Montgomery

1739.text: Never give up... No one knows what's going to happen next.
1739.author: L. Frank Baum

1740.text: I like good strong words that mean something…
1740.author: Louisa May Alcott

1741.text: What you do makes a difference, and you have to decide what kind of difference you want to make.
1741.author: Jane Goodall

1742.text: Yes, frosting. The final defense of the dying.
1742.author: Suzanne Collins

1743.text: The worst part of success is trying to find someone who is happy for you.
1743.author: Bette Midler

1744.text: I meant," said Ipslore bitterly, "what is there in this world that truly makes living worthwhile?"
1744.author: Terry Pratchett

1745.text: let me live, love, and say it well in good sentences
1745.author: Sylvia Plath

1746.text: I am not afraid of storms, for I am learning how to sail my ship.
1746.author: Louisa May Alcott

1747.text: May the forces of evil become confused on the way to your house.
1747.author: George Carlin

1748.text: Yes, I was infatuated with you: I am still. No one has ever heightened such a keen capacity of physical sensation in me. I cut you out because I couldn't stand being a passing fancy. Before I give my body, I must give my thoughts, my mind, my dreams. And you weren't having any of those.
1748.author: Sylvia Plath

1749.text: Today was good. Today was fun. Tomorrow is another one.
1749.author: Dr. Seuss

1750.text: A good book is an event in my life.
1750.author: Stendhal

1752.text: One day you will kiss a man you can't breathe without, and find that breath is of little consequence.
1752.author: Karen Marie Moning

1753.text: People who deny the existence of dragons are often eaten by dragons. From within.
1753.author: Ursula K. Le Guin

1754.text: Wisdom comes from experience. Experience is often a result of lack of wisdom.
1754.author: Terry Pratchett

1755.text: Peeta, you said at the interview you’d had a crush on me forever. When did forever start?
1755.author: Suzanne Collins

1756.text: Make your own Bible. Select and collect all the words and sentences that in all your readings have been to you like the blast of a trumpet.
1756.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

1757.text: He was my mum and dad's best friend. He's a convicted murderer, but he's broken out of wizard prison and he's on the run. He likes to keep in touch with me, though...keep up with my news...check if I'm happy...
1757.author: J.K. Rowling

1758.text: Once you had put the pieces back together, even though you may look intact, you were never quite the same as you'd been before the fall.
1758.author: Jodi Picoult

1759.text: Trying to define yourself is like trying to bite your own teeth.
1759.author: Alan Watts

1760.text: Isn't it enough to see that a garden is beautiful without having to believe that there are fairies at the bottom of it too?
1760.author: Douglas Adams

1761.text: I'm oxygen and he's dying to breathe.
1761.author: Tahereh Mafi

1762.text: There ain't no sin and there ain't no virtue. There's just stuff people do.
1762.author: John Steinbeck

1763.text: If I'd observed all the rules I'd never have got anywhere.
1763.author: Marilyn Monroe

1764.text: If things start happening, don't worry, don't stew, just go right along and you'll start happening too.
1764.author: Dr. Seuss

1765.text: Promise me you'll never forget me because if I thought you would, I'd never leave.
1765.author: A.A. Milne

1766.text: He was going to live forever, or die in the attempt.
1766.author: Joseph Heller

1767.text: A dream you dream alone is only a dream. A dream you dream together is reality.
1767.author: John Lennon

1768.text: What are all these?" Clary asked.
1768.author: Cassandra Clare

1769.text: To love oneself is the beginning of a lifelong romance.
1769.author: Oscar Wilde

1770.text: Pain insists upon being attended to. God whispers to us in our pleasures, speaks in our consciences, but shouts in our pains. It is his megaphone to rouse a deaf world.
1770.author: C.S. Lewis

1771.text: People worry about kids playing with guns, and teenagers watching violent videos; we are scared that some sort of culture of violence will take them over. Nobody worries about kids listening to thousands - literally thousands - of songs about broken hearts and rejection and pain and misery and loss.
1771.author: Nick Hornby

1772.text: If neurotic is wanting two mutually exclusive things at one and the same time, then I'm neurotic as hell. I'll be flying back and forth between one mutually exclusive thing and another for the rest of my days.
1772.author: Sylvia Plath

1773.text: The world is a dangerous place to live, not because of the people who are evil, but because of the people who don't do anything about it.
1773.author: Albert Einstein

1774.text: I'm not sentimental--I'm as romantic as you are. The idea, you know,
1774.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

1775.text: Did you know that for pretty much the entire history of the human species, the average life span was less than thirty years? You could count on ten years or so of real adulthood, right? There was no planning for retirement, There was no planning for a career. There was no planning. No time for plannning. No time for a future. But then the life spans started getting longer, and people started having more and more future. And now life has become the future. Every moment of your life is lived for the future--you go to high school so you can go to college so you can get a good job so you can get a nice house so you can afford to send your kids to college so they can get a good job so they can get a nice house so they can afford to send their kids to college.
1775.author: John Green

1777.text: It does not matter how slowly you go as long as you do not stop.
1777.author: Confucius

1778.text: Do not go gentle into that good night.
1778.author: Dylan Thomas

1779.text: And I asked myself about the present: how wide it was, how deep it was, how much was mine to keep.
1779.author: Kurt Vonnegut

1781.text: My tongue will tell the anger of my heart, or else my heart concealing it will break.
1781.author: William Shakespeare

1782.text: Most books on witchcraft will tell you that witches work naked. This is because most books on witchcraft were written by men.
1782.author: Neil Gaiman

1783.text: She was the heir of ash and fire, and she would bow to no one.
1783.author: Sarah J. Maas

1784.text: No one knows for certain how much impact they have on the lives of other people. Oftentimes, we have no clue. Yet we push it just the same.
1784.author: Jay Asher

1786.text: Don't wait for a light to appear at the end of the tunnel, stride down there and light the bloody thing yourself.
1786.author: Sara Henderson

1787.text: Believe nothing you hear, and only one half that you see.
1787.author: Edgar Allan Poe

1788.text: You yourself, as much as anybody in the entire universe, deserve your love and affection.
1788.author: Sharon Salzberg

1789.text: She leaned down and looked at his lifeless face and Leisel kissed her best friend, Rudy Steiner, soft and true on his lips. He tasted dusty and sweet. He tasted like regret in the shadows of trees and in the glow of the anarchist's suit collection. She kissed him long and soft, and when she pulled herself away, she touched his mouth with her fingers...She did not say goodbye. She was incapable, and after a few more minutes at his side, she was able to tear herself from the ground. It amazes me what humans can do, even when streams are flowing down their faces and they stagger on...
1789.author: Markus Zusak

1790.text: No matter what he does, every person on earth plays a central role in the history of the world. And normally he doesn't know it.
1790.author: Paulo Coelho

1791.text: The world is full of magic things, patiently waiting for our senses to grow sharper.
1791.author: W.B. Yeats

1792.text: For what it’s worth: it’s never too late or, in my case, too early to be whoever you want to be. There’s no time limit, stop whenever you want. You can change or stay the same, there are no rules to this thing. We can make the best or the worst of it. I hope you make the best of it. And I hope you see things that startle you. I hope you feel things you never felt before. I hope you meet people with a different point of view. I hope you live a life you’re proud of. If you find that you’re not, I hope you have the courage to start all over again.
1792.author: Eric Roth

1793.text: Only those who will risk going too far can possibly find out how far one can go.
1793.author: T.S. Eliot

1794.text: For whatever we lose (like a you or a me),
1794.author: e.e. cummings

1795.text: In the beginning there was nothing, which exploded.
1795.author: Terry Pratchett

1796.text: It is absurd to divide people into good and bad. People are either charming or tedious.
1796.author: Oscar Wilde

1797.text: Don't feel bad for one moment about doing what brings you joy.
1797.author: Sarah J. Maas

1798.text: Who in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle.
1798.author: Lewis Carroll

1800.text: Light thinks it travels faster than anything but it is wrong. No matter how fast light travels, it finds the darkness has always got there first, and is waiting for it.
1800.author: Terry Pratchett

1801.text: Never underestimate the power of stupid people in large groups.
1801.author: George Carlin

1802.text: People have forgotten this truth," the fox said. "But you mustn’t forget it. You become responsible forever for what you’ve tamed. You’re responsible for your rose.
1802.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

1803.text: My soul is from elsewhere, I'm sure of that, and I intend to end up there.
1803.author: Mawlana Jalal-al-Din Rumi

1804.text: Do not fall in love with people like me.
1804.author: Caitlyn Siehl

1805.text: You won’t understand what I mean now, but someday you will: the only trick of friendship, I think, is to find people who are better than you are—not smarter, not cooler, but kinder, and more generous, and more forgiving—and then to appreciate them for what they can teach you, and to try to listen to them when they tell you something about yourself, no matter how bad—or good—it might be, and to trust them, which is the hardest thing of all. But the best, as well.
1805.author: Hanya Yanagihara

1806.text: You're alive only once, as far as we know, and what could be worse than getting to the end of your life and realizing you hadn't lived it?
1806.author: Edward Albee

1807.text: I didn’t need you, you idiot. I picked you. And then you picked me back.
1807.author: John Green

1808.text: The creatures outside looked from pig to man, and from man to pig, and from pig to man again; but already it was impossible to say which was which.
1808.author: George Orwell

1809.text: There are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them.
1809.author: J. K. Rowling

1810.text: In a way, it's nice to know that there are Greek gods out there, because you have somebody to blame when things go wrong. For instance, when you're walking away from a bus that's just been attacked by monster hags and blown up by lightning, and it's raining on top of everything else, most people might think that's just really bad luck; when you're a half-blood, you understand that some devine force is really trying to mess up your day.
1810.author: Rick Riordan

1811.text: Only the dead have seen the end of war.
1811.author: Plato

1812.text: Love is the absence of judgment.
1812.author: Dalai Lama XIV

1813.text: People shouldn't be afraid of their government. Governments should be afraid of their people.
1813.author: Alan Moore

1814.text: We can know only that we know nothing. And that is the highest degree of human wisdom.
1814.author: Leo Tolstoy

1815.text: The library is inhabited by spirits that come out of the pages at night.
1815.author: Isabel Allende

1817.text: I knew, in the silence that followed, that anything could happen here. It might be too late: again, I might have missed my chance. But I would at least know I tried, that I took my heart and extended my hand, whatever the outcome.
1817.author: Sarah Dessen

1818.text: One thing you can't hide - is when you're crippled inside.
1818.author: John Lennon

1819.text: Everyone must leave something behind when he dies, my grandfather said. A child or a book or a painting or a house or a wall built or a pair of shoes made. Or a garden planted. Something your hand touched some way so your soul has somewhere to go when you die, and when people look at that tree or that flower you planted, you're there.
1819.author: Ray Bradbury

The beauty of a woman is seen in her eyes, because that is the doorway to her heart, the place where love resides. True beauty in a woman is reflected in her soul. It's the caring that she lovingly gives, the passion that she shows & the beauty of a woman only grows with passing years.

But never again use another person's body or emotions as a scratching post for your own unfulfilled yearnings.

1914.text: Lolita, light of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul. Lo-lee-ta: the tip of the tongue taking a trip of three steps down the palate to tap, at three, on the teeth. Lo. Lee. Ta. She was Lo, plain Lo, in the morning, standing four feet ten in one sock. She was Lola in slacks. She was Dolly at school. She was Dolores on the dotted line. But in my arms she was always Lolita. Did she have a precursor? She did, indeed she did. In point of fact, there might have been no Lolita at all had I not loved, one summer, an initial girl-child. In a princedom by the sea. Oh when? About as many years before Lolita was born as my age was that summer. You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style. Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, exhibit number one is what the seraphs, the misinformed, simple, noble-winged seraphs, envied. Look at this tangle of thorns.
1914.author: Vladimir Nabokov

1915.text: And thus the heart will break, yet brokenly live on.

And to understand the workings of our own heart we have to keep on making new reference cards. We have to dust things off every once in awhile, let in fresh air, change the water in the flower vases. In other words, you'll live forever in your own private library.

I stay with him because I choose to, every day that I wake up, every day that we fight or lie to each other or disappoint each other. I choose him over and over again, and he chooses me.

1974.text: It was a mistake," you said. But the cruel thing was, it felt like the mistake was mine, for trusting you.

1978.text: The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge.

1979.text: Are you implying that shreds of my reputation remain intact?" Will demanded with mock horror. "Clearly I have been doing something wrong. Or not something wrong, as the case may be."

1980.text: All parents damage their children. It cannot be helped. Youth, like pristine glass, absorbs the prints of its handlers. Some parents smudge, others crack, a few shatter childhoods completely into jagged little pieces, beyond repair.

1981.text: I drink to make other people more interesting.
1981.author: Hemingway Ernest

1982.text: Talk sense to a fool and he calls you foolish.
1982.author: Euripides

1984.author: T.S. Eliot

1985.text: Nobody tells this to people who are beginners, I wish someone told me. All of us who do creative work, we get into it because we have good taste. But there is this gap. For the first couple years you make stuff, it’s just not that good. It’s trying to be good, it has potential, but it’s not. But your taste, the thing that got you into the game, is still killer. And your taste is why your work disappoints you. A lot of people never get past this phase, they quit. Most people I know who do interesting, creative work went through years of this. We know our work doesn’t have this special thing that we want it to have. We all go through this. And if you are just starting out or you are still in this phase, you gotta know its normal and the most important thing you can do is do a lot of work. Put yourself on a deadline so that every week you will finish one story. It is only by going through a volume of work that you will close that gap, and your work will be as good as your ambitions. And I took longer to figure out how to do this than anyone I’ve ever met. It’s gonna take awhile. It’s normal to take awhile. You’ve just gotta fight your way through.
1985.author: Ira Glass

1986.text: Open your heart. Someone will come. Someone will come for you. But first you must open your heart.

1987.text: Is there no way out of the mind?

1988.text: If you know someone who’s depressed, please resolve never to ask them why. Depression isn’t a straightforward response to a bad situation; depression just is, like the weather.

1994.author: Dalai Lama XIV

1998.text: Do not be afraid; our fate
1998.author: Dante Alighieri
